abstract: New York City comptroller's office releases audit finding that hundreds of city's public housing units remain unnecessarily vacant; finds average vacancy of seven years for apartments that undergo major renovations; issue has contributed to shortage of affordable housing and has long plagued the New York City Housing Authority.
lead_paragraph: A report released by New York City’s comptroller, Scott M. Stringer, found that apartments remain vacant unnecessarily, either waiting for repairs for years or staying empty long after renovations.

headline.main: New York City Public Housing Units Remain Empty Unnecessarily, Audit Finds
headline.print_headline: Hundreds of Public Housing Units Are Unnecessarily Vacant, City Audit Finds

snippet: A report released by New York City’s comptroller, Scott M. Stringer, found that apartments remain vacant unnecessarily, either waiting for repairs for years or staying empty long after renovations.
